page.title: 01THE AREA AROUND SNAVE
page.content: Snave and its surroundings is one of the remotest sreas of the Rommney Marsh but it is bisected by the busy A2070 to Ashford and London and sees much through traffic. Characteristic of all this area is the flat landscape criss-crossed by the many drainage dykes. The land use is primarily intensively farmed cereals rotated with root crops and managed grassland which supports the local 'Rommney' sheep and a few cattle herds. Snave itself is so small, barely a hamlet, you enter and leave it in an instant. It has no amenities whatsoever and even the small but old chuch is in decline, the roof on the porch broken down, waiting repair. Services are held infrequently in rotation with other small marsh churches. The area does, however, contain a number of expensive large houses equiped with
